results.title: Andre Kertesz
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Master Photographers Series”.
Hungarian born Kertesz is considered the poet amongst photographers. In this film Kertesz talks explicitly about the influences on his work, his early life in Hungary, Paris in the 20’s, his colleagues and his friends, Chagall, Mondrian and Colette, and his bitter and long battle for acceptance in the United States.

results.title: Apocalypse now: redux [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola and Omni Zoetrope
results.brief_description: A stunning vision of man’s heart of darkness, revealed through the particular madness of the Vietnam War. Lieutenant Willard receives orders to seek out the renegade Colonel Kurtz, who has disappeared into the depths of the jungle. Willard’s mission becomes an epic journey into his own soul and that of the mysterious Kurtz. The trails of making this film are well documented, particularly within “Hearts of darkness: a filmmaker’s apocalypse” (1991) - Coppola’s financial, casting and location woes complicated his desire to deliver an anti-war work that would find an audience. In 2000 he began working on restoring key scenes, deleted in 1979, identifying those that expounded upon his themes of military madness and moral degradation. New scenes include: Willard’s seduction by a widow after attending a dinner at the home of a French plantation owner, the sumptuousness of which speaks of yearning for an idealised past and reflects Willard’s retreat from the present; the Playboy bunnies become stranded and Willard’s crew offer them fuel in exchange for sex, compounding the sense of the military’s ethical deprivation; Kurtz extrapolates upon the insanity of war, a philosophical scene linked to the denouement. Coppola’s original work won numerous accolades, but many critics questioned the rationale behind “Redux” and theorised that it perhaps reflected his failure to produce engaging work throughout the 1990s.

results.title: Bill Brandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Master Photographers Series”.
In this rare insight, Brandt shows some of his favourite photographs among them pictures of Paris in the 1920s, his compassionate scenes of Britain in the Depression, his Nudes and many distinguished portraits.

results.title: Antarctic Vigil
results.creator_credit: Film Australia and Dept of Interior for the Australian Film Board in association with The Australian National Anatarctic Research Expedition
results.brief_description: An account of research undertaken by Australian scientists at the Antarctic outposts of Macquarie, Kerguelen and Heard Islands. Shows life on these islands including work at the meteorological stations and studies of the unusual animal, bird and plant life found in Arctic regions.

results.title: Apocalypse now
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola and Omni Zoetrope
results.brief_description: Francis Ford Coppola’s stunning vision of man’s heart of darkness, revealed through the particular madness of the Vietnam War. Lieutenant Willard (Martin Sheen) receives orders to seek out the renegade Colonel Kurtz (Marlon Brando) who has disappeared into the depths of the jungle. Willard’s mission becomes an epic journey into his own soul and that of the mysterious Kurtz. Based on the novella by Joseph Conrad, “Heart of Darkness”. Original music by Carmine Coppola, Francis Ford Coppola, Mickey Hart.

results.title: Anzac: a nation's heritage
results.creator_credit: Lee Robinson, Denys Brown, Don Murray, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the landing by Australian and New Zealand troops on the Gallipoli Peninsula. Highlights include memorial services in Australia, New Zealand and Britain, a re-enactment at Anzac cove and scenes of Gallipoli and Troy today.

results.title: Antarctic Pioneers
results.creator_credit: Phillip Garth Law, Frank Hurley, Maslyn Williams, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: One of Australia’s most famous photographers and explorers, Frank Hurley, presents this absorbing film on the history of Australia’s first expeditions to the Antarctic continent between 1911 and 1954. It includes remarkable, original footage of the expedition on the tall ship Aurora in 1911, the Campbell expedition in 1947 and the Law expedition in 1954. Much of this film was made by Hurley when he accompanied Sir Douglas Mawson and an Australian party to the Antarctic in 1912 and on later expeditions. The program traces the history of the Australian expeditions between 1911 and 1914 and the establishment of Mawson Station. A rare film which reveals the true hardship and courage of these early pioneers.
